author: Sasha Abramsky is writing a book on changing attitudes toward crime and the expansion of the American prison system, to be published by St. Martin's Press.
body: AS the millennium draws to a close, a handful of New Yorkers prepare to enter their second century. Born in the 1890's, in the waning years of the Victorian era, they survived the turbulence of the 20th century and now, in their 11th decade, they prepare for the 21st. A century from now, centenarians may be a dime a dozen. But in 1999, they are
title: New York, When They Were Young

body: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract. title: Residential Resale

body: Imelda Marcos picking out yet another pair of shoes. Patricia Duff running through five teams of divorce lawyers. Donald Trump and his succession of leggy blondes. In the annals of the fickle, some people are giants. But alas, even among ordinary mortals, there has never been a shortage of caprice, whether in matters of the heart or the head, or in
title: Playing the Field for Phone Service; With Many Suitors, Customers Turn Fickle to Get Best Deal

body: The felt-tipped marker in Michel Trocme's hand sped across the easel, leaving an orange trail of ideas as the 30 people sitting around him each outlined a different vision of what kind of park to build at the foot of the Brooklyn Bridge. Nathan F. Elbogen, 38, a Gowanus artist and architect with a shaved head, rose to say he wanted studios and a
title: Disparate Visions for a New Park; Accord Is Sought Among Clashing Views in Brooklyn

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES

body: Pratt Institute, the Brooklyn-based art and design college, has purchased the upper six floors of a seven-story building on West 14th Street as a permanent home for its Manhattan operations. The school paid $11.5 million for 64,000 square feet of space at 144 West 14th Street, between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, and plans to
title: POSTINGS: $11.5 Million for Six Floors; Pratt Buys 14th St. Space

body: JAMAICA/FOREST HILLS Either Italian Baroque Or Modern Percussion Two concerts will be performed at two branches of the Queens Public Library on Saturday at 2 P.M., but although the times are the same the shows will be very different. The Ta Lujon Percussion Quartet will perform 20th-century percussion classics using an array of instruments from
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: To the Editor: Your article ''For Lovers of French Food, a Pocket of Paris Gets Bigger'' (Sept. 19) leaves the reader to believe that Fort Greene and Clinton Hill were devoid of respectable eating establishments until the recent influx from other boroughs and other countries. I beg to differ. For more than 25 years, Two Steps Down, a family-owned
title: Fort Greene Is Not A Culinary Wasteland

body: This week's primary election was, for many New Yorkers, a sleepy affair. But in Washington Heights, a race for Democratic district leader drew more than 2,000 voters and was, by any standard, furiously fought. Although district leader is considered the lowest rung of the ladder of elected offices, the candidates in this particular race, the latest
title: Political Notes; Big Battle for a Relatively Little Job

body: Work is nearing completion on a $10.5 million conversion of the turn-of-the-century St. Agnes elementary school in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn into a 90-unit middle-income rental apartment building. When completed next month, the Italian-Renaissance-style former school at 421 Degraw Street will have studio to three-bedroom units to be
title: RESIDENTIAL REAL ESTATE; Turning Old School Into Apartments

body: The sparse ballot for tomorrow's Democratic primary election in New York City includes two contests for Civil Court judgeships -- one in Manhattan and the other in Brooklyn. There is also a lopsided race for the post of Bronx District Attorney. These are our recommendations. Bronx District Attorney: The 10-year incumbent, Robert Johnson, faces a
title: For Civil Court and Bronx D.A.

body: HE swings open a small red gate at the end of the subway platform, ignoring the warning that reads ''Do Not Enter or Cross Tracks,'' and enters the dank tunnel just west of the Lafayette Avenue station in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn. A green light illuminates the youthful contours of his face as he saunters down the last narrow wedge of forbidden
title: From the Subways to the Streets

body: IN villages across Africa, storytelling has long been an integral part of daily life. At nights, even to this day, people gather in circles in courtyards illuminated by a full moon and bright stars to hear gripping tales from wise men and indelible stories from adventurous young men who have returned to their hamlets from faraway places. This and
title: New Roots for Black Culture

body: THE outdoor sculpture season is in full swing, with new works of all sorts punctuating New York at sites from Lincoln Center to Pier 34 downtown to Coffey Park in Red Hook, Brooklyn. Some are pieces of beauty and originality. But what makes a tour of this year's exhibitions interesting is not so much the level of artistic quality, which is not, on
title: ART REVIEW; A Fertile Garden Of Sculptures

body: IN Park Slope, Jerri Mayer has been begging her neighbors to hire exterminators, stop feeding the birds and cover their trash to fight a wave of rats that began marauding through the backyards of million-dollar brownstones this spring. In TriBeCa, where clans of as many as two dozen rats have made their homes in decorative sidewalk planters, Judy
title: The Rat Patrol

body: LONG ISLAND CITY Ethnic Diversity Celebrated On Feature Film Nights The next five Wednesday evenings at Socrates Sculpture Park, visitors may bring a blanket and enjoy an exotic mix of feature films from Brazil, Greece, Mexico, Africa and India -- celebrating the ethnic diversity of northwestern Queens. title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: A LOT of New Yorkers have no idea what a boiler looks like, let alone how one works. That's the beauty of being an apartment dweller. Maintenance is someone else's problem. But in the city's small co-ops, the ones that manage their own affairs, the mechanics of running the building aren't shuffled onto someone else. Someone on the board, or in the
title: Habitats /Clinton Hill, Brooklyn; A Co-op Owner Learns How to Be a Fixer-Upper

body: LOWER EAST SIDE Going to Teach at Rikers Inspires a One-Man Show Steven Tannenbaum's one-man show ''Q101'' focuses on his experiences working for two years as a teacher and an AIDS counselor on Rikers Island. title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

title: Tour Time: Spring Becomes the Northeast

body: Hoping to persuade more New York police officers to live in the city, the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development plans to offer about 250 houses at half price to law enforcement personnel who agree to live in them for at least three years, Federal officials announced yesterday. The houses, which the Government acquires through
title: Police Officers Get 250 More Reasons to Live in the City

body: A self-employed livery-cab driver was stabbed to death yesterday morning in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn by three men who were trying to rob him, the police said. The driver, Mohammed Hanif, a 40-year-old immigrant from Pakistan, was dropping off three passengers at the corner of Washington and Flushing Avenues in Brooklyn when they tried
title: Cabdriver, 40, Is Stabbed to Death in Brooklyn During an Attempted Robbery

body: AROUND report card time, there is no anxiety in the Brooklyn household of Lincoln and Marlene Nixon. Their son, Khari, 7, always has high marks and is ranked in the top percentile in both reading and math. But the Nixons do feel anxiety about the tax season, because of the usual bill from Uncle Sam; it averages roughly $1,000 a year, on top of the
title: YOUR TAXES; Saving for a College Education, Made Easier

title: SPARE TIMES

body: ON a water-logged day in Brooklyn, everything seems muted and muffled -- the grays and browns of the buildings, the soggy drumbeat of the rain, the leaden thwock of the car wheels shooting out sprays of oily water as they rumble over manhole covers. And then there is Rosie Perez, who, rain or shine, is about as muted and muffled as a stick of
title: FILM; Trying to Shake a Stereotype But Keep On Being Rosie Perez

body: LIKE many artists, Francisco Cardenas came to New York intent on making his mark in SoHo. ''You have to go outside of the familiar so that people will pay attention to you,'' he said. In his case, he had to go outside to help pay the bills. Recently, he took a construction job installing a smokestack at a restaurant at Houston Street and Second
title: About New York; Year of Rabbit Gives an Artist Some Luck
